titleStmt.title: Humphrey Minchin to Richard Bull; Richard Bull to Thomas Pennant

respStmt.name: Transcribed by Ffion Mair Jones; edited by Ffion Mair Jones; encoded by Vivien Williams. (2019)

div.p: The Ladys, to whom we are much obliged for making our little Party. (the great ones being over for this year) said you wish’d to know something about Southwick, I am not qualify’d to tell you much. When or by whom built I do not know, but suppose it not difficult to learn – Whether It was a Royal Seat, or only occasionally borrow’d, I cannot say, But Charles 1st. was at Prayers in the Chapel there, when the account was brought of the Assassination of the Duke of Buckingham by Felton at Portsmouth. in pencil: || George the 1st. was entertain’d there by Col. Norton, for some days; He attended the King to the Limits of the Forest of Bere, attended by sixty Keepers in Green Coats, then rode Post to London, & was full dress’d at St. James's Gate to receive his Majesty at his Arrival. underlined in pencil: I think the K. was shabby, for I do not find that He ask’d him to Dinner, or gave him one in Return, for all he had receiv’d) This Col. Norton by Will left Southwick, & all his Estates to the Parliament of Great Britain, in trust for the Poor, which will as suppos’d to proceed from Insanity, was set aside, & the Estate went to his Heirs by and is now in the Family of the Thistlewaite's, who came into the Line of Succession, in pencil: tho’ I do not know how. Further this Deponent saith not.

I write in a great Hurry being to go to the Land Revenue office. Secretary of State’s office Treasury then to send off a large Packet to Ireland then to the House on the Roman Catholic Bill The 1791 Relief Act allowed Catholics to declare a secular allegiance to the Hanoverian monarchy rather than insisting that they swore oaths of supremacy and a declaration against transubstantiation. OCRA s.v. Catholic emancipation. but I thought if this Information was worth Notice you would like to send it in your Cover to Mr. Pennant to day

I hope to get you a more satisfactory account than this – I mean with respect to the buildings &a: which are extremely large – the great Room, call’d the old Playhouse, is of very ancient date, and must have history belonging thereto, if we knew how to come at it. – had it been of much note in Edward VIs days, he would certainly have noted mention’d int in his letters to Barnaby Fitzpatrick, as he does every other great house, in the neighborhood of Portsmouth. My Volumes of the Wales, are all at the binders, and if I get them in 6 weeks I shall have better luck than I look for. I intend in the Spring to send Moses a list of all the drawings I have got in these books, and if he can furnish me with others, upon thin paper, and not too large for my Margins, I shall be glad; I mean arms as well as views. – You never sent me any etchings of Birds, by Moses Griffyths. – you have already given me, (I believe) all the etchings of the Barber of Edinburgh. – I dont hear any news of any kind, worth retailing.
